27. Regarding their Veil, or explanations concerning it,4 See Book II, 17-18. The “veil” is the threaded screen VM recommends as a grid for drawing.
I will here be silent, and instead discuss
copious and simple Histories
so that each may choose
which one their feelings most incline to:
but many good Masters avoid
the principles of abundance or Copia,
and do well with simplicity.
left-middleOn the Veil which I have discussed in the chapter on Drawing, on abundant and simple Histories.

28. Such masters (so to speak)
do not imitate Procurers or Lawyers,
who employ many words in pleading [a case],
but copy great Majesties
and powerful Potentates,
who do not put forth much talk
but give their meaning verbally,
or with their pen, in few words.
left-middleGreat masters do not create abundant histories, but resemble great Lords, who speak little yet keenly.

29. And such simple reasoning
earns them a greater reputation
than excessive babbling and prattling,
like empty vessels which make the most noise:
thus it seems that our great Masters learn
to turn towards plainness,
and how to give their objects
a beautiful bounty with few images.

30. And through that, great perfection is found
in their Figures, which move as if almost alive,
seemingly built on foundations
by poets who produced Comedy or Tragedy
to be performed with a few characters,
or they follow Varro, who did not seek
the great roar of many guests at the table
when he held festive banquets.
left-middleExample of simple Histories, in Theater, or at Banquets.

31. But in order to delight, according to his plan,
he chose a select group of people
and invited them to his banquet,
nine or ten, so that no one would prevent
another from enjoying himself.
However, in a simple mode, it is not praiseworthy
To depict crude or trivial things,
Which bring no harmony to the eyes.
left-middleCrude things in simple histories are not to be praised.

32. As Zephyr comes to meet Flora,
where, in former times, they would kiss,
and the many-hued songsters greet Aurora,
Yea, there the new blossoms seek the light;
the honey-seekers, who long for sweetness,
cannot always rest on Adonis;
they do not want to miss Crocus and Smilax,
left-middleSimilarity between a painting and a flowery field, where the eyes are like bees, happy among a variety of different artful blossoms.
